20110127170835.000|20110127170837.000|TR0|backgrounds, and so we don't look at this

20110127170840.000|20110127170842.000|TR0|by Ohio law, and I'm bound by our board

20110127171100.000|20110127171103.000|TR0|POE:  And, you know, that's a lesson that 
20110127171103.000|20110127171105.000|TR0|we tried -- we tried desperately to avoid 
20110127171105.000|20110127171108.000|TR0|that for two years.  And that's why we 
20110127171108.000|20110127171110.000|TR0|spent so much time from 2006 to 2008 
20110127171110.000|20110127171113.000|TR0|trying to work with the family.
20110127171113.000|20110127171115.000|TR0|
20110127171115.000|20110127171118.000|TR0|And it's a tragic situation, because the 
20110127171118.000|20110127171120.000|TR0|message that that sends is a difficult 
20110127171120.000|20110127171122.000|TR0|one.  But we're required to operate within 
20110127171122.000|20110127171125.000|TR0|state law. And in Ohio, in order to attend 
20110127171125.000|20110127171127.000|TR0|our school district, you need to reside in 
20110127171127.000|20110127171130.000|TR0|our school district.

20110127172229.000|20110127172231.000|TR0|

20110127172236.000|20110127172238.000|TR0|Switzerland.  For years, it's been an

20110127173327.000|20110127173330.000|TR0|know, I adhere to the philosophy of

20110127175534.000|20110127175537.000|TR0|new recruits. Now Afghanistan's prisons 
20110127175537.000|20110127175539.000|TR0|are becoming a prime breeding ground for 
20110127175539.000|20110127175542.000|TR0|terrorists. We'll take you there.
20110127175542.000|20110127175544.000|TR0|
20110127175544.000|20110127175547.000|TR0|(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
20110127175547.000|20110127175549.000|TR0|
20110127175549.000|20110127175552.000|TR0|COSTELLO: The Taliban continues to be an 
20110127175552.000|20110127175554.000|TR0|elusive enemy in the war in Afghanistan, 
20110127175554.000|20110127175557.000|TR0|but the very prisons that are supposed to 
20110127175557.000|20110127175559.000|TR0|reform them are proving to be a ripe 
20110127175559.000|20110127175602.000|TR0|recruitment center for terrorists. CNN's 
20110127175602.000|20110127175604.000|TR0|Arwa Damon has an inside look.
20110127175604.000|20110127175606.000|TR0|
20110127175606.000|20110127175609.000|TR0|(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
20110127175609.000|20110127175611.000|TR0|
20110127175611.000|20110127175614.000|TR0|ARWA DAMON, CNN CORRESPONDENT 
20110127175614.000|20110127175616.000|TR0|(voice-over): The prison in Mazer-e Sharif 
20110127175616.000|20110127175619.000|TR0|is like many in Afghanistan, overcrowded, 
20110127175619.000|20110127175621.000|TR0|unsanitary and, in the winter, bitterly 
20110127175621.000|20110127175624.000|TR0|cold. The makeshift cells at the bulk 
20110127175624.000|20110127175626.000|TR0|prison are so cramped that some prisoners 
20110127175626.000|20110127175629.000|TR0|are even forced to sleep outside.
20110127175629.000|20110127175631.000|TR0|
20110127175631.000|20110127175634.000|TR0|DAMON (on camera): We haven't been allowed 
20110127175634.000|20110127175636.000|TR0|to film inside, but this jail was 
20110127175636.000|20110127175639.000|TR0|originally built as a house. And now there 
20110127175639.000|20110127175641.000|TR0|are around 450 prisoners here, literally 
20110127175641.000|20110127175643.000|TR0|living stacked one on top of another.
20110127175643.000|20110127175646.000|TR0|
20110127175646.000|20110127175648.000|TR0|DAMON (voice-over): Around half of the 
20110127175648.000|20110127175651.000|TR0|prisoners are ordinary criminals, but the 
20110127175651.000|20110127175653.000|TR0|rest are Taliban, and the prison is their 
20110127175653.000|20110127175656.000|TR0|perfect recruiting ground.      GEN. 
20110127175656.000|20110127175658.000|TR0|MOHAMED AZIZ, MAZER-E SHARIF, AFGHANISTAN 
20110127175658.000|20110127175701.000|TR0|(through translator): According to the 
20110127175701.000|20110127175703.000|TR0|law, they should be held in separate 
20110127175703.000|20110127175706.000|TR0|facilities. We have serious criminals, 
20110127175706.000|20110127175708.000|TR0|like the Taliban, next to those who have 
20110127175708.000|20110127175711.000|TR0|committed small crimes. It's a constant 
20110127175711.000|20110127175713.000|TR0|worry for us.
20110127175713.000|20110127175716.000|TR0|
20110127175716.000|20110127175718.000|TR0|DAMON: Aziz says Taliban fighters 
20110127175718.000|20110127175720.000|TR0|typically target vulnerable youth and drug 
20110127175720.000|20110127175723.000|TR0|addicts. Islamudin, serving time for 
20110127175723.000|20110127175725.000|TR0|carjacking, started using opium behind 
20110127175725.000|20110127175728.000|TR0|bars. The 27-year-old says he's clean now 
20110127175728.000|20110127175730.000|TR0|and swears the Taliban never tried to 
20110127175730.000|20110127175733.000|TR0|recruit him. Aziz says it's a typical 
20110127175733.000|20110127175735.000|TR0|response. His spies behind bars have told 
20110127175735.000|20110127175738.000|TR0|him otherwise.
20110127175738.000|20110127175740.000|TR0|
20110127175740.000|20110127175743.000|TR0|It's a problem across Afghanistan, 
20110127175743.000|20110127175745.000|TR0|according to the official in charge of the 
20110127175745.000|20110127175748.000|TR0|country's jails.
20110127175748.000|20110127175750.000|TR0|
20110127175750.000|20110127175753.000|TR0|AMIR JAMSHED, GENERAL PRISONS PRESIDENT 
20110127175753.000|20110127175755.000|TR0|(through translator): This is very risky. 
20110127175755.000|20110127175757.000|TR0|If we put 1,000 Taliban behind bars, they 
20110127175757.000|20110127175800.000|TR0|will recruit 1,000 more prisoners.
20110127175800.000|20110127175802.000|TR0|
20110127175802.000|20110127175805.000|TR0|DAMON: At this balk prison workers are 
20110127175805.000|20110127175807.000|TR0|building extensions to separate the 
20110127175807.000|20110127175810.000|TR0|prisoners. Similar projects are underway 
20110127175810.000|20110127175812.000|TR0|around the country.
20110127175812.000|20110127175815.000|TR0|
20110127175815.000|20110127175817.000|TR0|JAMSHED: We are also continuing with a 
20110127175817.000|20110127175820.000|TR0|deradicalization program. There are two 
20110127175820.000|20110127175822.000|TR0|groups of Taliban, the ideologues and 
20110127175822.000|20110127175825.000|TR0|those who join for economic reasons. They 
20110127175825.000|20110127175827.000|TR0|can be reeducated.
20110127175827.000|20110127175830.000|TR0|
20110127175830.000|20110127175832.000|TR0|DAMON: The results have been not bad he 
20110127175832.000|20110127175834.000|TR0|says. This is a religious class at Kabul's 
20110127175834.000|20110127175837.000|TR0|Poly (ph) Turkey (ph) prison, intended to 
20110127175837.000|20110127175839.000|TR0|lure prisons away from extremism. It 
20110127175839.000|20110127175842.000|TR0|doesn't always work. One inmate told us he 
20110127175842.000|20110127175844.000|TR0|went from being an Afghan nationalist to 
20110127175844.000|20110127175847.000|TR0|believing the Taliban is the only solution.
20110127175847.000|20110127175849.000|TR0|
20110127175849.000|20110127175852.000|TR0|Afghanistan's prisons have become another

20110127175854.000|20110127175857.000|TR0|future. And it's far from clear who has 
20110127175857.000|20110127175859.000|TR0|the upper hand.
